docs.lead_paragraph: More and more children are taking up golf. But as they do, a good number of them are ending their day in the emergency room instead of the clubhouse. A new study in The Journal of Neurosurgery reports that head injuries are becoming a growing problem for younger players. The biggest dangers are errant swings and golf cart mishaps.
docs.abstract: Dr Scott Y Rahimi of Medical College of Georgia in Augusta, home of Masters Golf Tournament, leads study that shows golf-related injuries are on rise among young people as more and more of them play game; head injuries from golfing accidents are found to be second most common sports injury, behind bicycle accidents; study is published in Journal of Neurosurgery; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: More and more children are taking up golf. But as they do, a good number of them are ending their day in the emergency room instead of the clubhouse.

docs.lead_paragraph: When there is an extraordinary new outbreak of a well-known disease, it can provide new insights into how the disease is spread. A case in point is Chagas' disease, which exists only in the Americas, where it has infected an estimated 16 million people and causes about 50,000 deaths each year.

headline.main: Lessons of the Kissing Bug's Deadly Gift

docs.abstract: Chagas disease, which is primarily transmitted by bite of kissing bug, is found to be transmitted orally through contaminated sugar cane juice; outbreak, which took place in Santa Catarina, Brazil, is particularly deadly and symptoms of disease that generally take years to surface are developing within days after ingestion of tainted juice; outbreak is being investigated by several agencies, including World Health Organization; photo (M)
docs.snippet: When there is a new outbreak of a well-known disease, it can provide new insights into how the disease is spread. Chagas' disease is a case in point.

docs.lead_paragraph: New mothers who want to breast-feed have long been advised, even by health care workers, to have a drink to help them relax and produce milk. The recommended drink varies -- often it is beer, sometimes it is wine -- but the advice has popped up in cultures around the world for centuries. Now in a new study, researchers say that when they hooked women up to breast pumps and measured their output, they found that those who had drunk alcohol took longer to release their milk and produced less. The study, led by Dr. Julie A. Mennella of the Monell Chemical Senses Center in Philadelphia, appears in The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism.
docs.abstract: Dr Julie A Mennella of Monell Chemical Senses Center leads study that dispels idea that nursing mother will relax and produce more milk for baby if she has drink before nursing; study, which is published in Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism, finds that women who drink alcohol take longer to release their milk and produce less; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: New mothers who want to breast-feed have long been advised, even by health care workers, to have a drink to help them relax and produce milk, but it may be unnecessary.

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors often hesitate to prescribe sleeping pills to people in nursing homes out of concern that the medication may lead their patients to fall and injure themselves. But a new study suggests that it is insomnia, not the pills, that may be responsible for many falls. Writing in The Journal of the American Geriatrics Society, researchers from the University of Michigan say that doctors should more seriously consider using hypnotics, a sleeping aid, for older people who have trouble sleeping.

headline.main: A New Culprit in Nighttime Falls

docs.abstract: Dr Alon Y Avidan of University of Michigan leads study on nursing home patients that suggests use of sleep aids does not increase risk for falls; study, which is published in Journal of the American Geriatrics Society, instead shows increase in falls among elderly patients who suffer from untreated insomnia; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new study suggests that it is insomnia, not the pills used to treat it, that may be responsible for many nursing-home falls.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN GERIATRIC SOCIETY

docs.lead_paragraph: Women are thought to be far more concerned about affairs of the heart than men. But when it comes to diseases of the heart, women and their doctors are paying far too little attention. According to recently published studies in Circulation, the journal of the American Heart Association, women are inadequately cared for in terms of preventing heart disease and in diagnosing and treating it.

headline.main: Women Struggle for Parity of the Heart

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column urges women to become more aware of their level of heart disease risk, follow doctor's guidelines and make better life style choices to keep heart healthy; cardiovascular disease is top killer of American women and half million women die of it each year; testing and treatment discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: When it comes to diseases of the heart, women and their doctors are paying far too little attention.

docs.lead_paragraph: His teenage patient is dressed in a khaki work suit and flip-flops, reclining in the dental chair as Dr. James Strohschein probes with his mirror and says, ''Huh!'' Anticipating the diagnosis, his patient mumbles: ''Yeah, crystal meth. It broke my tooth.''

headline.main: Filling a Need (and a Tooth) in America's Poorest Pockets

docs.abstract: Lack of new dentists in United States to replace those retiring has created shortage of dentists in many communities in need of care; Dr James Strohschein, New Mexico School of Medicine surgery and dental services assistant professor, describes program designed to help New Mexico's juvenile offenders get seen and treated by dentists; research shows that no improvement in dental care has been made since 2000 Surgeon General's report on oral health in America, which called dental and oral diseases silent epidemic and urged improvements; programs designed to encourage more individuals to go into dentistry described; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that not even one in five children in US are seen by dentist (M)
docs.snippet: According to most authorities on oral health, dental care for Americans has not improved since a recent surgeon general's report, and there are many indications that it is getting worse.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: Christine Stanley will never forget the call. Two weeks after her daughter Emily started kindergarten, the teacher phoned in a panic. Emily would not color, sing or participate in any classroom activities; in fact, she would not say a word to anyone. It was not the first time Christine had received such a call. Emily had not talked at preschool, either. She did not make eye contact with store clerks or talk to nurses at the pediatrician's office. She ran off the playground if another child approached.

headline.main: The Child Who Would Not Speak A Word

docs.abstract: Selective mutism is often misunderstood condition in which children stop communicating both verbally and non-verbally in certain social situations, but remain communicative within family environment; disorder has been inappropriately linked with child abuse and children with it are mistakenly regarded as willful and manipulative since it outwardly appears that they control when symptoms appear; experts hold that selective mutism likely represents extreme social anxiety brought on by child's perception that they are in danger; research shows that disorder is nearly twice as common as autism and can be treated in many cases with combination of drug and cognitive therapies; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Selective mutism  when, in social situations, children are silent and withdrawn  is a disorder nearly twice as common as autism.

docs.lead_paragraph: My mother died of emphysema a couple of years ago. I was there when she died and the image of her gasping for breath will not go away. But what clings to me even more is the grief I feel about what she felt about her death, which was shame.

headline.main: In a Judgmental World, She Was Ashamed of Getting Sick

docs.abstract: Gretchen Cook Cases column talks about death of her mother from emphysema; asserts that patients who are ill from diseases linked to life style choices, like smoking, experience guilt and feel they caused their own illness; some doctors feel it is better for some patients to not know exact cause of illness; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Is there is a link between the shame a patient feels and the course of an illness?

docs.lead_paragraph: A child whose grandmother smoked during pregnancy may have almost twice the risk of developing asthma as one whose grandmother did not smoke -- even if the child's mother was a nonsmoker, a new study has found. The study, published in the April issue of the journal Chest, is the first to show that smoking in pregnancy can harm not only a woman's children, but her grandchildren as well.

headline.main: Child's Asthma Linked To Grandmother's Habit

docs.abstract: Dr Frank D Gilliland, Keck School of Medicine preventive medicine professor, leads study that suggests risk of child developing asthma is increased when mother smokes, but also when grandmother smokes; holds that reason for findings is unclear, but link warrants more research; study, which is published in journal Chest, involved subjects participating in Southern California Children's Health Study (M)
docs.snippet: A child whose grandmother smoked during pregnancy may have almost twice the risk of developing asthma as one whose grandmother did not smoke, a new study has found.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Crossing your legs causes varicose veins. THE FACTS It's not often that an old wives' tale inspires a national movement. But in 1999, a company that makes dietary supplements started a campaign -- the ''Great American Cross-Out'' -- to stop women from crossing their legs for a day, saying the practice contributes to poor circulation and the development of varicose veins.
docs.abstract: Research shows no link between crossing legs and development of varicose veins; drawings (S)
docs.snippet: More than 12 large studies that have looked at the risk factors for varicose veins have not found leg-crossing to be one of them.
